unnormalised: Okay, here's a Quora post on "Training Regimens" in the "Sports" category:
normalised: What are some unique training regimens you have seen or used that yielded surprising results?

unnormalised: **What are some unique training regimens you've seen or used that yielded surprising results?**
normalised: Hey everyone! Training regimens are fascinating, aren't they? We all know about the usual stuff – strength training, cardio, et cetera. But I am curious about those unconventional methods that actually work wonders.

unnormalised: Hey everyone! Training regimens are fascinating, aren't they? We all know about the usual stuff – strength training, cardio, etc. But I'm curious about those unconventional methods that actually work wonders.
normalised: I once saw a young kabaddi player, Rohan from Jaipur, train by running up and down Amer Fort steps repeatedly, every day at six hundred hours. He swore it built incredible leg strength and endurance. It looked brutal, but his raiding skills improved drastically!

unnormalised: I once saw a young kabaddi player, Rohan from Jaipur, train by running up and down Amer Fort steps repeatedly, every day at 06:00 hrs. He swore it built incredible leg strength and endurance. It looked brutal, but his raiding skills improved drastically!
normalised: Another example: my uncle, a former marathon runner, used to practice "fartlek" training around Cubbon Park in Bangalore, mixing sprints with slow jogs. He claimed it was key to his personal best in the nineteen eighty two Asian Games qualifier. Apparently, the unpredictable bursts really built his stamina.

unnormalised: Another example: my uncle, a former marathon runner, used to practice "fartlek" training around Cubbon Park in Bangalore, mixing sprints with slow jogs. He claimed it was key to his personal best in the 1982 Asian Games qualifier. Apparently, the unpredictable bursts really built his stamina.
normalised: Anyone here tried something similar? Maybe some yogic breathing exercises incorporated into a cricket training program? Or perhaps a weightlifting routine focusing on functional strength for badminton, instead of pure mass? I am thinking beyond just hitting the gym and lifting heavy.

unnormalised: Anyone here tried something similar? Maybe some yogic breathing exercises incorporated into a cricket training program? Or perhaps a weightlifting routine focusing on functional strength for badminton, instead of pure mass? I'm thinking beyond just hitting the gym and lifting heavy.
normalised: I remember reading somewhere that Milkha Singh, before fifteenth august nineteen forty seven, used to train so rigorously he would collapse from exhaustion! I do not recommend that extreme, of course, but it shows the dedication. What about your experiences? Let us hear your stories! What worked for you (or someone you know) that might sound a bit odd but got amazing results? Even if its something you saw at the N I S Patiala!
